doc.previous: In greatest dimension, the island is 93 miles (150Â km) across and has a land area of 4,028 square miles (10,430Â km2)[7] comprising 62% of the Hawaiian Islands' land area. Measured from its sea floor base to its highest peak, Mauna Kea is the world's tallest mountain, taller than Mount Everest is, with Everest being above sea level.[8]
after: The Island of HawaiÊ»i is built from five separate shield volcanoes that erupted somewhat sequentially, one overlapping the other. These are (from oldest to youngest):

Geological evidence from exposures of old surfaces on the south and west flanks of Mauna Loa led to the proposal that two ancient volcanic shields (named Ninole and Kulani) were all but buried by the younger Mauna Loa.[9] Geologists now consider these "outcrops" to be part of the earlier building of Mauna Loa.
